message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing sexual side effects from the current medication, fluoxetine. Bupropion is an antidepressant that has less sexual side effects compared to other antidepressants, making it the appropriate choice for switching the patient’s medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing sexual side effects of fluoxetine, which is a common side effect of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). Bupropion, which is not an SSRI, is a good alternative for treating depression and does not cause sexual side effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), commonly causes sexual dysfunction as a side effect. Bupropion is an antidepressant that works differently and does not typically cause sexual dysfunction. Therefore, it is the most appropriate drug to switch the patient to. Options A, B, and C are all also antidepressants, but they have a higher likelihood of causing sexual dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing sexual side effects of fluoxetine, which is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Bupropion, which is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI), is a good alternative to SSRIs for patients experiencing sexual side effects. Citalopram is another SSRI and would likely produce similar side effects. Tranylcypromine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) and is not a first-line treatment for depression. Trazodone is primarily used as a sleep aid and is not a first-line treatment for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The side effect of delayed ejaculation and anorgasmia suggests that the current medication, fluoxetine, is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Bupropion is a dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, and can be used as an alternative antidepressant that does not have sexual side effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing sexual dysfunction as a side effect of fluoxetine. Bupropion is a drug that does not have sexual side effects and can be used to replace fluoxetine in this patient. Citalopram is also an option, but it can cause sexual side effects in some patients, so bupropion is a better choice in this case. Tranylcypromine and trazodone are not first-line treatments for depression and are not indicated in this case.

Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor that does not have these side effects and can be used as an alternative for patients who experience sexual dysfunction with SSRIs.
